medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Benign prostatic hyperplasia. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Benign prostatic hyperplasia. OPERATION PERFORMED: Transurethral electrosurgical resection of the prostate. ANESTHESIA: General. COMPLICATIONS: None. INDICATIONS FOR THE SURGERY: This is a 77-year-old man with severe benign prostatic hyperplasia. He has had problem with urinary retention and bladder stones in the past. He will need to have transurethral resection of prostate to alleviate the above-mentioned problems. Potential complications include, but are not limited to: 1. Infection. 2. Bleeding. 3. Incontinence. 4. Impotence. 5. Formation of urethral strictures. PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: The patient was identified, after which he was taken into the operating room. General LMA anesthesia was then administered. The patient was given prophylactic antibiotic in the preoperative holding area. The patient was then positioned, prepped and draped. Cystoscopy was then performed by using a #26-French continuous flow resectoscopic sheath and a visual obturator. The prostatic urethra appeared to be moderately hypertrophied due to the lateral lobes and a large median lobe. The anterior urethra was normal without strictures or lesions. The bladder was severely trabeculated with multiple bladder diverticula. There is a very bladder diverticula located in the right posterior bladder wall just proximal to the trigone. Using the ***** resection apparatus and a right angle resection loop, the prostate was resected initially at the area of the median lobe. Once the median lobe has completely resected, the left lateral lobe and then the right lateral lobes were taken down. Once an adequate channel had been achieved, the prostatic specimen was retrieved from the bladder by using an Ellik evacuator. A 3-mm bar electrode was then introduced into the prostate to achieve perfect hemostasis. The sheath was then removed under direct vision and a #24-French Foley catheter was then inserted atraumatically with pinkish irrigation fluid obtained. The patient tolerated the operation well.
layman:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Enlarged prostate (benign prostatic hyperplasia).  
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Enlarged prostate (benign prostatic hyperplasia).  
OPERATION PERFORMED: Cutting and removing part of the prostate through the urethra using electric surgery.  
ANESTHESIA: General (the patient was fully asleep).  
COMPLICATIONS: None.  

INDICATIONS FOR THE SURGERY:  
A 77‑year‑old man has a very enlarged prostate that has caused him to have trouble urinating and has led to bladder stones. Surgery is needed to relieve these problems. Possible risks include infection, bleeding, leaking urine, loss of sexual function, and narrowing of the urethra.  

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:  
The patient was identified and taken to the operating room. He was given general anesthesia with a laryngeal mask airway. A preventive antibiotic was given before the surgery. The patient was positioned, cleaned, and covered.  

A cystoscope (a small camera) was inserted through the urethra using a 26‑French sheath and a visual guide. The prostate’s urethra looked moderately enlarged because of the side lobes and a large middle lobe. The front part of the urethra was normal. The bladder was heavily scarred with many outpouchings, including a large one on the right side just above the trigone.  

Using a resection device and a right‑angle loop, the surgeon first removed the middle lobe of the prostate. After that, the left side lobe and then the right side lobe were removed. When a clear channel was made, the prostate tissue was taken out of the bladder with an Ellik evacuator. A 3‑mm electrode was then used to stop any bleeding. The sheath was removed while watching the area, and a 24‑French Foley catheter was inserted gently with pinkish irrigation fluid. The patient tolerated the operation well.
